LABEL: 01_QUESTION
TEXT: Title

LABEL: 01_EXPLAIN
TEXT: What is the working title of your study? It is helpful if this is the same title that you submit for publication of your final manuscript, but it is not a requirement.

LABEL: 01_HELP
TEXT: Effect of sugar on brownie tastiness.

LABEL: 02_QUESTION
TEXT: Authorship

LABEL: 02_EXPLAIN
TEXT: The first author of the pre-registered study is the recipient of the award money and must also be the first author of the published manuscript. Additional authors may be added or removed at any time.

LABEL: 02_HELP
TEXT: Jimmy Stewart, Ava Gardner, Bob Hope, Greta Garbo

LABEL: 03_QUESTION
TEXT: Conflict of Interest

LABEL: 03_EXPLAIN
TEXT: Could the results of this project benefit the financial interests of any of its authors, or be reasonably perceived to do so?

LABEL: 03_HELP
TEXT: The authors of this study own a majority share of Tastee Sugar Company.

LABEL: 04_QUESTION
TEXT: Research questions and hypotheses

LABEL: 04_EXPLAIN
TEXT: What are your research questions and hypotheses?

LABEL: 04_HELP
TEXT: There is strong evidence to suggest that sugar affects taste preferences, but the effect has never been demonstrated in brownies. Therefore, we will measure taste preference for four different levels of sugar concentration in a standard brownie recipe. If taste effects preferences, then mean preference indices will be higher with higher concentrations of sugar.

LABEL: 05_QUESTION
TEXT: Data collection procedures.

LABEL: 05_EXPLAIN
TEXT: Please describe the process by which you will collect the data. This may include the population from which you obtain subjects, recruitment efforts, how subjects will be selected for eligibility from the initial pool (e.g. inclusion and exclusion rules), and your study timeline.

LABEL: 05_HELP
TEXT: Participants will be recruited through advertisements at local pastry shops. Participants will be paid $10 for agreeing to  participating (raised to $30 if our sample size is not reached within 15 days of beginning recruitment). Participants must be at least 18 years old and be able to eat the ingredients of the pastries.

LABEL: 06_QUESTION
TEXT: Sample Size

LABEL: 06_EXPLAIN
TEXT: What is your sample size? How many units will be analyzed in the study? This could be the number of people, birds, classrooms, plots, interactions, or countries included. If the units are not individuals, then describe the size requirements for each unit. If you are using a clustered/multilevel design, how many units are you collecting at each level of the analysis?

LABEL: 06_HELP
TEXT: Our target sample size is 280 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 320, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

LABEL: 07_QUESTION
TEXT: Sample size rationale

LABEL: 07_EXPLAIN
TEXT: This could include a power analysis or an arbitrary constraint such as resource availability. Include a stopping rule.

LABEL: 07_HELP
TEXT: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. We will stop recruiting participants at 320 (to account for incomplete data) or after 30 days, whichever comes first.

LABEL: 08_QUESTION
TEXT: Please check and certify one of the following statements

LABEL: 08_MC01
TEXT: I certify that none of the data that will be used in this upcoming study have yet been collected. Please enter your name and the phrase "I certify" in the following box. Why is this necessary?

LABEL: 08_MC02
TEXT: I will be using pre-existing data in this study. I certify that I have no knowledge about any of its basic descriptive statistics, nor am I aware of any differences or relationships within the data that I will use. Please enter your name and the phrase _I certify in the following boxes."

LABEL: 09_QUESTION
TEXT: Study type

LABEL: 09_MC01
TEXT: Experiment (A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment or a randomized controlled trial.

LABEL: 09_MC02
TEXT: Observational Study (Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, natural experiments, and regression discontinuity designs.)

LABEL: 09_MC03
TEXT: Meta-Analysis (a systematic review of published studies)

LABEL: 09_MC04
TEXT: Other (please explain)

LABEL: 10_QUESTION
TEXT: Blinding

LABEL: 10_MC01
TEXT: Not applicable: This study will not assign treatments to subjects (e.g. observational studies or meta-analyses).

LABEL: 10_MC02
TEXT: Yes, single blind: Human subjects of the study will not know if they are assigned to a treatment or control group. Experimenters will have that knowledge.

LABEL: 10_MC03
TEXT: Yes, double blind: Neither the human subjects, nor the experimenters taking measurements from a subject will have knowledge of the treatment.

LABEL: 10_MC04
TEXT: No: both human subjects and researchers are aware of the treatment groups.

LABEL: 10_MC05
TEXT: Yes: I am using non-human study subjects, and researchers collecting data are ignorant of each subject's treatment group.

LABEL: 10_MC06
TEXT: No: researchers are aware of the treatment groups.

LABEL: 11_QUESTION
TEXT: Study design

LABEL: 11_EXPLAIN
TEXT: Describe your study design. Examples include two-group, factorial, randomized block, and repeated measures. Is it a between or within-subject design? Describe any counterbalancing required. Typical study designs for observation studies include cohort, cross sectional, and case-control studies. You will be asked to define your variables in detail in the upcoming sections.

LABEL: 11_HELP
TEXT: In our between-subject design, each of the 280 expected participants will taste one of the four levels of brownies (1X4)

LABEL: 12_QUESTION
TEXT: Predictor variable(s)

LABEL: 12_EXPLAIN
TEXT: Define your predictor or independent variable(s). If you have categorical predictors, describe the levels for each. If your predictor variables are constructed from multiple measurements, you will be asked later on to describe how they are created.

LABEL: 12_HELP
TEXT: Our predictor is the amount of sugar added per brownie. The dry ingredients for each brownie will contain 15%, 20%, 25%, or 40% cane sugar by mass.

LABEL: 13_QUESTION
TEXT: Outcome variable(s)

LABEL: 13_EXPLAIN
TEXT: Define your outcome or dependent variable(s). If your outcome measurements are constructed from multiple measurements, you will be asked later on to describe how they are created.

LABEL: 13_HELP
TEXT: The single outcome variable will be the perceived tastiness of the single brownie each participant will eat.

LABEL: 14_QUESTION
TEXT: Covariates

LABEL: 14_EXPLAIN
TEXT: Describe any covariates. If applicable, and not mentioned above, what covariates, controls, or other variables will you measure?

LABEL: 14_HELP
TEXT: We will be collecting basic demographic information from each participant (age, household income, education level, housing zipcode, and marital status) and use that information for exploratory data investigation to determine if taste perception may be easily predicted. Any suggestive correlations may be the subject of future, confirmatory investigations.

LABEL: 15_QUESTION
TEXT: Randomization

LABEL: 15_EXPLAIN
TEXT: If you are doing a randomized study, how will you randomize, and at what level? There are many different randomization techniques. [link https://osf.io/x5w7h/wiki/06%20Stats%20Glossary%20and%20Tips/]

LABEL: 15_HELP
TEXT: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the four equally sized, predetermined blocks. The random number list used to create these four blocks will e created using the web applications available at http://random.org.

LABEL: 16_QUESTION
TEXT: Constructing predictor variables

LABEL: 16_EXPLAIN
TEXT: Sometimes, a main predictor will not be a single measurement, but an index made from several other measurements. What measures will you use and how will they be combined to make your predictor variable(s).

LABEL: 16_HELP
TEXT: The predictor variable (percent sugar) will not be constructed from multiple measures.

LABEL: 17_QUESTION
TEXT: Constructing outcome variables

LABEL: 17_EXPLAIN
TEXT: Just as with the previous question, how will specific measures be combined to create your ouctome variable(s)?

LABEL: 17_HELP
TEXT: As taste perception is a complex variable, we will measure it by taking each users geometric mean response from three widely used indices of tastiness: the Tasty Measure Index of Sweetness (1-100 scale), the Yum Scale of Enjoyability (1-10 scale), and the Aural Pleasure Rating of Foods (1-20 scale). A geometric mean will be used because of the scale variation between each of the three indices.

LABEL: 18_QUESTION
TEXT: Data exclusion

LABEL: 18_EXPLAIN
TEXT: How will you determine what data or samples (if any) to exclude from your analyses? How will outliers be handled? You may want to attach a decision tree with an "if, then structure to easily formalize the way in which these decisions will be made.

LABEL: 18_HELP
TEXT: No checks will be performed to determine eligibility for inclusion besides verification that each subject answered each of the three tastiness indices. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

LABEL: 19_QUESTION
TEXT: Incomplete or missing data

LABEL: 19_EXPLAIN
TEXT: How will you deal with incomplete or missing data? Many studies will have missing data points. How you cope with these missing points is important because it can affect the result of your analysis.

LABEL: 19_HELP
TEXT: If any of the three indices of tastiness are not completed by a subject, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

LABEL: 20_QUESTION
TEXT: Statistical models

LABEL: 20_EXPLAIN
TEXT: What statistical model(s) will you use to test your hypothesis(ses)? Please include the type of model (e.g. ANOVA, regression, SEM, etc) as well as the specification of the model (e.g. what variables will be included). If you are using a method other than null hypothesis significance testing, such as a Bayesian method, provide the criteria you will use for making an evidence-based conclusion. Include likely alternative analyses or data transformations. This may be another item where a decision tree could be helpful.

LABEL: 20_HELP
TEXT: We will use a 1x4 ANOVA to analyze our results. The categorical independent variable is _sugar whereas the dependent variable, _taste, is continuous. If the the ANOVA indicates that the mean taste perceptions are significantly different (p<.05), then we will use a Tukey-Kramer HSD test to determine the differences between levels. We will test the assumption of the ANOVA on equal group variance using the Bartlett test and use a Kruskal-Wallis if p<.05.

LABEL: 21_QUESTION
TEXT: Multiple comparisons

LABEL: 21_EXPLAIN
TEXT: If you are comparing multiple conditions or testing multiple hypotheses, how will you account for this?

LABEL: 21_HELP
TEXT: The only possible instance of requiring adjustment or acknowledgement of multiple comparisons would be the six combinations among the four levels of the independent variable tested in the ANOVA, which will only be investigated if indicated by the ANOVA results by a Tukey HSD.

LABEL: 22_QUESTION
TEXT: (Optional) Upload an analysis script with clear comments.

LABEL: 22_EXPLAIN
TEXT: This optional step is helpful in order to create a process that is completely transparent and increase the likelihood that your analysis can be replicated. We recommend that you run the code on a simulated dataset in order to check that it will run without errors.

LABEL: 22_HELP
TEXT: Here is a link to the R script that we will use to run the ANOVA. It also contains the code for the Tukey HSD we will run if needed. https://osf.io/kexgi/
